abstracts.cdata!:
The major physical components of the
            Second Urban Transport Project for Brazil were successfully
            completed and at a cost below appraisal estimates. The
            TRENSURB rapid transit line was constructed and technical
            assistance was provided to establish its management and
            operating company. However, the failure to implement
            complementary measures is having a negative effect on
            TRENSURB's operational and financial performance. The
            ultimate success of the project is contingent on the
            resumption of economic growth in the region and on the
            implementation of complementary measures such as bus
            integration and car parking restrictions. The most serious
            shortcoming of the project was the failure to undertake and
            implement a public transport tariff study as originally
            envisaged. One major lesson learned is that, in cases where
            there is a need for substantial policy and implementation
            decisions involving different levels of Government agencies
            subject to conflicting political and social pressures, their
            commitment should be realistically assessed during
            preparation. Regarding the original objective of TRENSURB
            covering its working costs, the appraisal was unrealistic to
            expect that this would take place during the initial
            operation period. The rail system must first demonstrate its
            reliability to users. In the meantime, TRENSURB should
            undertake a staff review to streamline costs and conduct a
            tariff study to determine the optimal user charges. The Bank
            should closely follow up the implementation of these tasks.
